results_summary: The study successfully designed a process involving gel-breaking, coagulation, and precipitation to remove HPG from fracturing fluids, achieving reinjection standards. The method was characterized as environmentally friendly and cost-effective, with detailed analysis using SEM, EDX, XRD, and FTIR.
population_specificity: Not applicable (industrial application, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a guar gum-based composite material for adsorbing heavy metal ions (Cu2+ and Co2+) in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The guar gum composite demonstrated high adsorption capacities (709 mg g-1 for Cu2+ and 601 mg g-1 for Co2+), with chemisorption as the primary mechanism, and exhibited good chemical stability in recycling studies.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the controlled release of mebendazole from ethyl cellulose nanofibers containing guar gum and its effect on the mortality of hydatid cyst protoscoleces.
results_summary: Guar gum nanofibers at concentrations of 10, 50, 250, and 500 ppm showed drug release rates of 42.09%, 39.95%, 33.05%, and 30.96% after 312 hours, respectively, and achieved 100% protoscolex mortality within 3-13 days.
population_specificity: Hydatid cyst protoscoleces under laboratory conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of guar gum (GG) as a hydrophilic agent in a membrane for purifying water contaminated with CTAB and congo-red dye.
results_summary: The GG/UiO-66 membrane demonstrated excellent hydrophilicity, self-healing properties, and effective pollutant separation, enhancing recyclability and sustainability. The central composite design highlighted operational parameters influencing removal efficiency.
population_specificity: Contaminated water samples (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of bentonite-supported zero-valent metal catalysts, particularly zero-valent copper, in Fenton-like oxidation processing for treating waste fracturing fluid containing hydroxypropyl guar gum (HPGG).
results_summary: The study found that bentonite-supported zero-valent copper exhibited the best catalytic performance, achieving a 76% chemical oxygen demand removal rate for HPGG under optimal conditions (45 min reaction time). The catalyst also demonstrated good stability after recycling.
population_specificity: Waste fracturing fluid containing HPGG (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on catalyst dosage, H2O2 concentration, temperature, and pH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of guar gum-based edible coatings on extending the shelf life and preserving the quality of blackberries stored at 5°C.
results_summary: The study found that a 0.3% guar gum coating combined with perforated clamshells reduced deterioration and preserved blackberries for 13 days, though with high weight loss (23.23%). A 0.3% guar gum coating with polylactic acid film maintained samples for 12 days with minimal weight loss (1.75%).
population_specificity: Blackberry fruits (cv. Castilla)
effective_dosage: 0.3% and 0.4% guar gum solutions in water

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether voluntary exercise could enhance the effects of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) on gut microbiota, obesity, and glucose tolerance in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Voluntary exercise combined with PHGG treatment significantly reduced obesity and improved glucose tolerance in mice on a high-fat diet. Exercise also accelerated beneficial changes in gut microbiota, particularly lowering the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio.
population_specificity: 4-week-old male C57BL/6J mice (n = 80)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a guar gum-based non-viral gene delivery vehicle for gene therapy in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
results_summary: The guar gum-based carrier demonstrated cytocompatibility, excellent blood compatibility up to 200 μg/ml, high gene binding capability, and superior in vitro transfection efficiency in TNBC cells compared to lipofectamine 2000.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 (TNBC) and HeLa cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of guar gum as a natural coagulant for treating landfill leachate, optimizing its performance in Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) removal.
results_summary: The study found that guar gum achieved 22.57% COD removal at an optimal dosage of 44.39 mg/L, pH 8.56, and mixing speed of 79.27 rpm. Structural analysis indicated that hydrogen bonding and adsorption mechanisms contributed to pollutant removal.
population_specificity: Landfill leachate (wastewater treatment context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) could reduce radiotherapy-induced diarrhea, improve bacterial count, nutrition status, and quality of life in pelvic cancer patients.
results_summary: PHGG supplementation increased bifidobacterial count and reduced diarrhea frequency after pelvic radiation completion, though initial diarrhea frequency was higher in the intervention group. The effect was significant after controlling for confounders.
population_specificity: Adult pelvic cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy (mean age 56.5 ± 10.8 years, 75% malnourished).
study_duration: 14 days prior to and 14 days during pelvic radiation (total 28 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a chitosan/cationic guar gum hydrogel for phosphate removal from wastewater and evaluate its potential as a supercapacitor electrode material.
results_summary: The CS/CGG hydrogel effectively adsorbed phosphate from wastewater, fitting the Freundlich model, and the phosphate-adsorbed hydrogels were converted into porous N,P-doped carbon aerogels with excellent capacitive performance (302.2 ± 4.9 F/g) and cycling stability.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanoformulation of amphotericin B and piperine using guar gum to enhance bioavailability and reduce toxicity for antileishmanial therapy.
results_summary: The guar gum-based nanoparticles demonstrated controlled drug release, protection from acidic pH, and effective suppression of Leishmania donovani growth in vitro and in vivo, with 96% parasite inhibition and no nephrotoxicity.
population_specificity: Golden hamster-L. donovani model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the microbiota-modulating effects of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) in healthy human subjects.
results_summary: PHGG significantly improved stool frequency and consistency, altered gut microbiota diversity, increased beneficial metabolites (e.g., butyrate, acetate), and induced taxonomic shifts favoring Ruminococcus, Fusicatenibacter, and Faecalibacterium while reducing Roseburia and Lachnospiracea. Most effects reversed post-intervention and were more pronounced in males.
population_specificity: 20 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 5 g PHGG up to three times per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a green synthesis method for silver nanoparticles using alginate-guar gum blend (GG-Alg@Ag) and evaluate its effectiveness in degrading methylene blue dye in wastewater.
results_summary: The study demonstrated successful synthesis of GG-Alg@Ag nanoparticles, achieving 92.33% photodegradation of methylene blue under optimized conditions (pH 4.98, 194 mg L-1 dye concentration, 0.07 g catalyst dose, 120 min exposure). The degradation mechanism followed a pseudo-second-order model, with the composite showing a bandgap energy of 2.5 eV.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel nanoparticle system (FITC-SiO2@Au-DOX-GGS-FA NPs) using guar gum succinate for targeted cancer imaging and combined chemo/photothermal therapy.
results_summary: The NPs demonstrated improved cellular uptake in HeLa cells via folate-receptor-mediated endocytosis, pH-sensitive drug release, and enhanced cytotoxicity due to tumor-targetability and combined DOX/photothermal effects. The NPs were also effective for dual CT/fluorescence imaging.
population_specificity: HeLa cells (in vitro cancer cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of guar gum modified with salicylhydrazine in removing Ni2+, Co2+, and Cr3+ from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The modified guar gum demonstrated high adsorption capacities for nickel (1272.4 mg•g-1), chromium (748.86 mg•g-1), and cobalt (521.81 mg•g-1), fitting the Langmuir model. The adsorption mechanism was confirmed through 1H NMR titration, indicating exothermic behavior and suitability for water purification.
population_specificity: Aqueous solutions (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high- and medium-molecular-weight partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) on gut microbiota modulation and constipation relief in mice.
results_summary: PHGG increased fecal moisture, improved small intestinal transit, and shortened the time to first defecation after constipation. High-dose medium-molecular-weight PHGG showed the highest short-chain fatty acid production and promoted beneficial gut microbiota changes.
population_specificity: Constipation-induced mice.
effective_dosage: 250 mg/kg bw (low dose) and 1 g/kg bw (high dose) for HHGG and MHGG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) against oxidative damage and its probiotic functions in d-galactose-induced aging rats.
results_summary: PHGG treatment at 1500 mg/kg/day significantly reduced oxidative stress markers, improved antioxidant enzyme activity, and enhanced intestinal microbiota composition. It also alleviated oxidative damage in the liver and hippocampus and upregulated beneficial protein expressions.
population_specificity: Rats injected with d-galactose to induce aging-related injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of guar gum (GG) as an enzyme-triggered capping agent for controlled drug release in a multimodal nanoplatform targeting colorectal cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that guar gum effectively capped the 5FU-loaded nanoplatform, showing zero-release in simulated GI conditions until triggered by colonic enzymes, enabling targeted drug delivery. The nanoplatform demonstrated enhanced therapeutic efficacy in HT-29 CRC cells when combined with enzyme-triggered release and photodynamic therapy.
population_specificity: HT-29 colon carcinoma cell lines (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a curcumin-loaded hydrogel (Cur-NPs/OGG/SF) for wound healing applications, focusing on its physicochemical properties and biological effects.
results_summary: The hydrogel showed improved degradation behavior with increased OGG content, enhanced cell proliferation without cytotoxicity, and exhibited antibacterial activity against Bacillus and E. coli. The results suggest the hydrogel is suitable for wound healing.
population_specificity: Mouse embryonic fibroblast (NIH-3T3) cells and bacterial strains (Bacillus and E. coli).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) could protect against acute alcohol-induced liver injury by examining its effects on mitochondrial integrity, oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis.
results_summary: PHGG attenuated liver damage markers, improved antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced inflammation via TLR4 signaling, and inhibited apoptosis in both in vitro and in vivo models. It also enhanced lipid metabolism and mitochondrial protection.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (in vitro) and acute alcohol-intoxicated mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate non-thermal plasma-assisted surface-modified CMGG/CS hydrogels for biomedical applications, focusing on pH-responsive drug delivery and biofilm eradication.
results_summary: The hydrogels showed pH-responsive swelling, effective diclofenac sodium release for colon-targeted drug delivery, excellent biofilm eradication against E. coli, hemocompatibility, and biodegradability.
population_specificity: Human RBCs (in vitro) and bacterial biofilm (E. coli).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel nanoparticle (TPGS-g-guar gum) as a drug delivery system for borneol to improve its solubility and drug-loading capacity for treating central nervous system illnesses.
results_summary: The study found that TPGS-g-guar gum nanoparticles effectively carried borneol and released the drug, suggesting potential for improving treatment of central nervous system and cerebrovascular diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize guar gum-zero valent iron nanocomposites (ZGNC) and evaluate their effectiveness in pollutant treatment.
results_summary: The study found that ZGNC effectively adsorbed ciprofloxacin (94% removal efficiency) and catalyzed the oxidation of methyl orange (99% efficiency) within 60 minutes under specific pH conditions. The nanocomposites exhibited clear physicochemical properties and elemental composition.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of galacylhydrazine modified guar gum (GG-GH) in removing organic dyes from water samples.
results_summary: GG-GH demonstrated highly efficient removal of organic dyes, achieving equilibrium in 0.5 hours with maximum adsorption capacities ranging from 868.83 to 1522.2 mg g-1 for different dyes. The material maintained high removal efficiency (>95%) even after ten filtration-regeneration cycles, indicating excellent recyclability and long-term usability.
population_specificity: Water samples (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on material performance rather than dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (study measured performance over filtration-regeneration cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of nutraceuticals, including Guar Gum, on infantile colic, functional abdominal pain, and irritable bowel syndrome in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention specific findings related to Guar Gum.
population_specificity: Infants, children, and adolescents with abdominal pain and gut-brain interaction disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the physicochemical and biological properties of artificial tear components, including Guar Gum, and their efficacy in managing dry eye disease.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Guar Gum's effects, only mentioning a general review of artificial tear components and formulations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of dry eye disease management).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a prebiotic formulation containing partially hydrolysed guar gum and acacia gum altered the composition, richness, and diversity of the gut microbiota in adults with functional constipation.
results_summary: The prebiotic formulation significantly reduced species richness and Shannon diversity in the gut microbiota of the treatment group, though functional composition remained unchanged. The control group did not exhibit these changes.
population_specificity: 61 adults with functional constipation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of extracted and isolated fibers, including guar gum, in reducing appetite and energy intake in healthy adults.
results_summary: Acute intakes of guar gum were observed to frequently result in reductions in appetite ratings, with viscous fibers like guar gum showing more consistent benefits compared to non-viscous fibers. However, the overall evidence base was varied due to methodological differences and limited research on many fibers.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
study_duration: Acute (short-term) and chronic (long-term) studies included, but exact duration for guar gum not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Guar Gum on glycemia, including fasting plasma glucose, post-prandial plasma glucose, and insulin resistance in humans.
results_summary: The study found that Guar Gum had positive effects on glycemia, improving fasting and post-prandial plasma glucose levels, as well as insulin resistance. It was highlighted as one of the nutraceuticals with potential benefits for managing prediabetes and diabetes.
population_specificity: Humans with dysglycemia (impaired fasting glycemia or impaired glucose tolerance), prediabetes, or diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize literature on gastrointestinal effects of Guar Gum and other NDCs to establish tolerable intake dose recommendations.
results_summary: The study found that Guar Gum's tolerance was NDC-specific, with gastrointestinal effects such as bloating and flatulence noted, but no severe adverse effects were reported. Tolerable intake levels varied among NDCs, though specific recommendations for Guar Gum were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults without gastrointestinal disease.
effective_dosage: Doses ranged from 0.75-160 g/d (specific Guar Gum dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Ranged from a single-meal tolerance test to 28 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) on gastric emptying, small intestinal transit, intestinal hormone levels, and feelings of hunger and satiety compared to fructooligosaccharide (FOS) and a placebo.
results_summary: PHGG reduced small intestinal transit compared to placebo but did not significantly affect gastric emptying, intestinal hormone levels, hunger, satiety, or desire to eat. FOS increased gastric emptying, while both fibers reduced small intestinal transit without altering other measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy participants
effective_dosage: 20 g of PHGG in a single test meal

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) on bowel movements, plasma bile acids, quality of life, and gut microbiota in healthy volunteers with IBS-D-like symptoms.
results_summary: PHGG significantly improved stool form (normalized Bristol stool scale) but had no effect on stool frequency. It also altered the gut microbiota composition, increasing certain beneficial bacteria.
population_specificity: 44 healthy volunteers (22 males, 22 females, average age 41.9 ± 6.3 years) with frequent bowel movements and loose stools (Bristol stool scale 5-6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term physiological effects and tolerability of partially-hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) in mild-to-moderate symptomatic gastroparesis patients.
results_summary: The study compared PHGG, gum Arabic, psyllium husk, and water, suggesting that low-viscosity soluble fibers like PHGG could be tolerable for gastroparesis patients, though specific efficacy results for PHGG were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Mild-to-moderate symptomatic gastroparesis patients (primarily female, some with Type-1 or Type-2 diabetes) not requiring enteral tube feeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a whey/guar preload on gastric emptying, postprandial glycaemia, and HbA1c levels in people with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The whey/guar preload slowed gastric emptying, reduced postprandial blood glucose levels, and modestly lowered HbA1c compared to placebo, without affecting energy intake, body weight, or body composition. The effects were sustained over 12 weeks.
population_specificity: People with well-controlled type 2 diabetes managed on diet or metformin.
effective_dosage: 5 g guar gum plus 17 g whey protein, taken twice daily before meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fiber-containing foods and supplements, including partially hydrolyzed guar gum, on digestive health outcomes in children.
results_summary: The review found that partially hydrolyzed guar gum, glucomannan, and bran showed beneficial effects on digestive health outcomes in children, though the evidence was not conclusive. Limited data existed on whole-grain fiber sources like oats.
population_specificity: Children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of probiotics versus a guar gum-containing nutritional supplement in preventing severe diarrhoea in cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy (with or without chemotherapy).
results_summary: The study found that grade 3 or 4 diarrhoea occurred less often in the probiotics group compared to the guar gum group (OR 0.38, 95% CI 0.16 to 0.89), suggesting probiotics may be more effective. However, the evidence was of low certainty due to study limitations.
population_specificity: Cancer patients receiving radiotherapy (with or without chemotherapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two glutamine supplements (glutamine-fiber-oligosaccharide and glutamine F) on bowel movement in elderly inpatients starting enteral feeding.
results_summary: Glutamine F administration resulted in significantly lower stool frequency and harder stools compared to glutamine-fiber-oligosaccharide, suggesting different effects due to additive components.
population_specificity: Elderly inpatients (>75 years) recovering from critical illness in non-intensive care units.
effective_dosage: 9 g/day of glutamine, administered three times daily.
study_duration: Duration of the study (exact length not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of high-viscosity soluble fibers like guar gum in providing health benefits such as cholesterol lowering, improved glycemic control, and normalizing stool form.
results_summary: The study found that high-viscosity soluble fibers like guar gum significantly improve cholesterol levels and glycemic control, and they effectively normalize stool form by resisting dehydration in the large bowel. Nonviscous or insoluble fibers did not provide these benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on clinical outcomes in well-controlled studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of hydrolyzed guar gum with lactulose in treating functional childhood constipation.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in the number of stools per week between hydrolyzed guar gum and lactulose (MD 1.00, 95% CI -1.80 to 3.80). No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Children aged 0 to 18 years with functional constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the beneficial effects of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) as a non-pharmacologic treatment for pediatric irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The study found some evidence supporting the beneficial effects of PHGG in managing pediatric IBS, alongside other interventions like cognitive behavioral therapy and probiotics. The efficacy was noted in a systematic review of 24 studies, though specific details on PHGG's impact were not isolated.
population_specificity: Children with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGIDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synbiotic supplementation (including Guar Gum) combined with nutritional counseling improved metabolic parameters, hepatic steatosis, and gut health in NASH patients compared to nutritional counseling alone.
results_summary: The synbiotic group (including Guar Gum) showed reduced hepatic steatosis, weight loss, decreased BMI, and reduced waist circumference, but no improvement in intestinal permeability or LPS levels.
population_specificity: 50 biopsy-proven NASH patients
effective_dosage: Not specified (combined with Lactobacillus reuteri and inulin)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of guar gum and other polysaccharides on postprandial glucose, appetite responses, and subsequent food intake when added to milk.
results_summary: Guar gum significantly suppressed post-treatment glucose and average appetite (p < 0.0001) and reduced caloric intake at a subsequent meal, with effects more pronounced than alginate but less pronounced in blood glucose reduction compared to alginate.
population_specificity: 30 females aged 18-30 years.
effective_dosage: 2.5 g guar gum added to 250 ml milk.
study_duration: Single administration with follow-up measurements over 120 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel co-processed fiber composite (FC) containing guar gum could blunt and sustain postprandial glucose and insulin responses compared to maltodextrin in healthy adults.
results_summary: The FC significantly reduced postprandial glucose and insulin responses after breakfast and showed a modest glycemic reduction after lunch in both beverage and bar forms compared to maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Young, nondiabetic, nonobese adults
study_duration: Single testing days separated by at least 1 week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a guar gum-based hydrogel (CQ-01) in treating severe and intractable pruritus associated with burn-induced hypertrophic scars.
results_summary: CQ-01 provided significant symptomatic relief, with a mean JW score reduction of 36 compared to baseline, and was safe, with only minor skin irritation reported in 8% of patients. The effect lasted up to 3 days and showed no tachyphylaxis with repeated applications.
population_specificity: 74 patients with burn-induced hypertrophic scars and severe pruritus.
effective_dosage: 24-hour application of CQ-01 hydrogel (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Single application with follow-up assessments up to 7 days; repeated applications were also studied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize clinical studies on Guar Gum's effects on appetite control in normal subjects and propose its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Guar Gum delayed colonic transit time, stimulated satiety hormone CCK, and prolonged post-meal satiation, reducing inter-meal calorie intake by about 20%. Doses of 2g/serving provided sustained satiation, while >5g/serving or combined with protein showed acute satiety effects.
population_specificity: Normal subjects
effective_dosage: 2g/serving for sustained effects; >5g/serving or 2.6g Guar Gum + 8g protein/serving for acute effects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) on symptom relief in constipation-predominant IBS patients, focusing on gender, age, and BMI.
results_summary: PHGG administration significantly improved symptom scores, laxative/enema use, stool consistency, and colonic transit time. Improvements varied by gender, age, and BMI, with notable benefits in women, patients ≥45 years, and those with BMI ≥25 for evacuations, and in males, younger patients, and those with BMI <25 for bloating.
population_specificity: 68 patients with constipation-predominant IBS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of guar gum on postprandial blood pressure in older adults with postprandial hypotension.
results_summary: Guar gum significantly reduced the prevalence of postprandial hypotension compared to placebo (18.2% vs. 72.7%) and showed significant differences in systolic and diastolic blood pressure changes over time.
population_specificity: Twenty-two older female adults aged 67 to 88 with postprandial hypotension.
effective_dosage: 9 grams of guar gum mixed with semi-fluid food.
study_duration: Two treatment phases with a 1-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) added to oral rehydration solution (ORS) reduces diarrhea duration, stool output, and enhances weight gain in malnourished children with acute diarrhea.
results_summary: PHGG added to ORS significantly reduced the duration of diarrhea and improved weight gain, though stool output reduction trends were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 126 malnourished children aged 6-36 months with acute diarrhea (<7 days) and weight-for-length/weight-for-age < -3 Z-score, with or without pedal edema.
effective_dosage: 15 g/L of PHGG added to modified WHO ORS.
study_duration: Intervention duration was monitored over 72 hours (3 days) for stool output, with follow-up for weight gain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Guar Gum in improving irritable bowel syndrome symptom frequency in children with abdominal pain-related functional gastrointestinal disorders.
results_summary: Guar Gum significantly improved irritable bowel syndrome symptom frequency, but no effect was found for other fiber supplements. The study did not report serious adverse effects.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-18 years with abdominal pain-related functional gastrointestinal disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the degree of immune reactivity (IgG and IgE antibodies) to guar gum and other gums in the general population.
results_summary: The study found that 4.2%-27% of specimens showed elevated IgG antibodies against guar gum, while 15.6%-29.1% showed elevated IgE antibodies. A subgroup of individuals produced both IgG and IgE antibodies, suggesting potential hidden immune reactivities.
population_specificity: 288 commercially sourced sera representing the general population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of guar gum as an add-on therapy to bezafibrate in reducing cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolaemia.
results_summary: Guar gum, when added to bezafibrate, reduced total cholesterol and LDL levels compared to bezafibrate alone, though the study did not assess long-term outcomes or primary clinical endpoints.
population_specificity: Children and adults with familial hypercholesterolaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relative available energy (RAE) of partially hydrolysed guar gum compared to other dietary fiber materials based on fermentability from breath hydrogen excretion.
results_summary: The study found that partially hydrolysed guar gum had a relative available energy (RAE) of 1 kcal/g based on the area under the curve (AUC) of breath hydrogen excretion (BHE) over 8 hours, similar to other tested dietary fibers. Extending the collection period to 14 or 24 hours also yielded an RAE of 1 kcal/g for all tested fibers, including guar gum.
population_specificity: Subjects (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract)
study_duration: Breath hydrogen collection occurred over 24 hours post-ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of guar gum-based polymers as controlled release formulations for therapeutic delivery, particularly via the oral route.
results_summary: The study found that guar gum-based polymers are effective as controlled release formulations in various forms (microspheres, nanoparticles, hydrogels, matrix tablets) for delivering diverse therapeutics, with a focus on oral administration due to its convenience and patient compliance.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) on colonic transit time and symptoms of chronic constipation.
results_summary: PHGG significantly reduced colonic transit time, increased bowel movement frequency, improved stool form, and decreased straining, laxative use, and abdominal pain in patients with chronic constipation.
population_specificity: Patients fulfilling Rome III criteria for chronic constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether maintenance therapy with partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) reduces recurrence rates and improves success rates in patients with healed chronic anal fissure (CAF) after treatment with glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) ointment.
results_summary: PHGG maintenance therapy significantly reduced recurrence rates (14.5% vs. 30.2%) and increased success rates (58.5% vs. 38.3%) at 12-month follow-up compared to no maintenance therapy. The results were statistically significant (P = 0.019 for success rate, P = 0.0047 for recurrence rate).
population_specificity: Patients with healed chronic anal fissure (CAF) after standard therapy with topical GTN 0.4% ointment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Guar Gum could attenuate postprandial reductions in blood pressure.
results_summary: Three studies demonstrated that Guar Gum statistically attenuated postprandial reductions in blood pressure, though most studies did not include individuals with symptomatic postprandial hypotension.
population_specificity: Adults, primarily without symptomatic postprandial hypotension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of low-dose guar gum, alone or combined with whey protein, on postprandial glycemia, insulin, GLP-1, and gastric emptying in type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Low-dose guar gum (5g) was less effective than whey protein or the whey-guar combination in reducing postprandial glycemia and did not slow gastric emptying. The combination of whey and guar showed significant glucose-lowering effects, associated with delayed gastric emptying.
population_specificity: 21 patients with type 2 diabetes managed by diet or metformin alone.
effective_dosage: 5g guar gum, administered once as a preload before a meal.
study_duration: Acute effects measured over 240 minutes post-meal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Guar Gum as a therapeutic intervention for women with cholestasis of pregnancy.
results_summary: Guar gum caused mild abdominal distress, diarrhoea, and flatulence during the first days of treatment. The study concluded there is insufficient evidence to indicate that Guar Gum is effective in treating women with cholestasis of pregnancy.
population_specificity: Women with a clinical diagnosis of obstetric cholestasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Guar Gum on mucin secretion in the small intestine compared to other fibers.
results_summary: The study found that Guar Gum did not significantly increase luminal mucin or goblet cell count compared to the fiber-free control group, unlike some other fibers tested.
population_specificity: Wistar rats and Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if guar gum compression-coated tablets could effectively target flurbiprofen delivery to the colon while minimizing side effects in the upper gastrointestinal tract.
results_summary: The optimized guar gum-coated formulation (F4) achieved nearly complete drug release in the colon (99.86%) within 24 hours, with minimal drug loss (6.84%) during the initial 5-hour lag period. Pharmacokinetic data confirmed colon targeting, showing delayed peak concentration (Tmax 10h vs. 3h for immediate-release tablets) and higher bioavailability (AUC 78214.50 vs. 40385.78 ng-h/mL).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and pharmacokinetic study, no human subjects mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (optimized formulation F4 used, but exact guar gum dosage not stated).
study_duration: 24-hour dissolution study; pharmacokinetic parameters measured post-administration (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety, efficacy, and clinical applications of Partially Hydrolyzed Guar Gum (PHGG) as a dietary fiber for managing functional gastrointestinal disorders in adults and children.
results_summary: PHGG was found to be safe and effective in treating IBS symptoms (both constipation and diarrhea), chronic constipation, and improving gut health in enteral nutrition. It also showed potential in reducing diarrhea incidence in clinical nutrition and optimizing antibiotic use in SIBO treatment.
population_specificity: Adults (healthy volunteers and patients with IBS, constipation, enteral nutrition needs, SIBO) and children with functional abdominal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) on metabolic syndrome (MetS) and cardiovascular risk factors in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: PHGG supplementation reduced waist circumference, HbA1c, urinary albumin excretion, and serum trans-fatty acids in patients with type 2 diabetes and MetS, but did not affect other MetS components or inflammatory markers. The control group only showed weight reduction.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome (44 participants, 38.6% male, mean age 62 years, mean diabetes duration 14.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the tolerance and effectiveness of a prebiotic inulin/partially hydrolyzed guar gum mixture (I-PHGG) for treating constipation in females and its impact on gut microbiota and short-chain fatty acid production.
results_summary: I-PHGG showed comparable clinical results to placebo in improving bowel movement frequency and patient satisfaction but reduced pathogenic Clostridium sp. in the gut microbiota. No significant changes in short-chain fatty acid profiles were observed.
population_specificity: 60 constipated female health workers reporting fewer than 3 bowel movements per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) with lactulose for treating constipation in children.
results_summary: PHGG was as effective as lactulose in improving bowel movement frequency, stool consistency, and reducing abdominal pain, with fewer reported side effects like flatulence and bad taste. Parents were more satisfied with PHGG treatment.
population_specificity: 61 children with constipation (31 in PHGG group, 30 in lactulose group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if guarana powder could prevent liver damage and oxidative stress induced by high doses of paracetamol in rats.
results_summary: Guarana significantly reduced liver damage markers (ALT, AST, ALP) and oxidative stress, prevented necrosis, and enhanced antioxidant defenses in rats treated with paracetamol.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining partially hydrolysed guar gum with rifaximin was more effective than rifaximin alone in treating small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).
results_summary: The combination of rifaximin and partially hydrolysed guar gum showed a significantly higher eradication rate of SIBO (87.1% per-protocol, 85.0% intention-to-treat) compared to rifaximin alone (62.1%). Clinical improvement was similar in both groups (86.9% vs. 91.1%).
population_specificity: Patients with a positive glucose breath test and predisposing conditions to SIBO (n=77).
effective_dosage: 5 g/day of partially hydrolysed guar gum.
